titleStmt.title: Microstructure and mechanical properties of refractory high entropy (Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTi) BCC /M 5 Si 3 in-situ Compound

analytic.title: Microstructure and mechanical properties of refractory high entropy (Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTi) BCC /M 5 Si 3 in-situ Compound

biblStruct.note: Received Date: 14 June 2015 Revised Date: 3 November 2015 Accepted Date: 14 November 2015

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Refractory high-entropy alloy Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTi is selected as the base alloy and element Si is added for preparing the (Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTi) BCC /M 5 Si 3 in-situ compound. The effect of Si on the microstructure and mechanical properties of Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTi alloy is analyzed and discussed. The base alloy has the single body-centered cubic (BCC) phase. After adding Si, the alloy is composed of one BCC phase and the intermetallic M 5 Si 3 phase with hexagonal close-packed (HCP) crystal structure. The microstructure gradually evolves from the hypoeutectic structure to eutectic structure and finally to hypereutectic structure with the increase of Si concentration. The addition of Si reduces the density and increases the hardness and strength of the base alloy due to the formation of M 5 Si 3 phase. The plasticity of Si 0.1 alloy is also improved due to the grain refinement and the weakening of the solution strengthening for the dominant BCC phase and the M 5 Si 3 phase is fine while the plasticity decreases due to the formation of more brittle M 5 Si 3 phase with a larger size as Si content increases.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The development of the aircraft and aerospace industry is making new demands on materials suitable for more elevated temperature applications and more excellent properties at elevated temperatures. The incipient melting point of Ni based super-alloys sets a limitation to the working temperature to 1100 o C [1]. Refractory alloys are considered as possible candidates for elevated temperature applications, taking advantage of their outstanding intrinsic properties, notably the high melting points and their very good mechanical and creep strength [2].

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
div.p: In recent years, many researchers have paid much attention on a new alloy system named high entropy alloys due to their simple phase constitutes, microstructure and excellent properties [3][4][5][6][7][8][9].

The serious lattice distortion due to the presence of different atoms at lattice points and the sluggish diffusion endow most high-entropy alloys with high thermal stability. The other diffusion-related processes like recrystallization and grain growth are much slower in high-entropy alloys compared with the traditional alloy systems. The above characteristics make high entropy alloys be alternative elevated temperature structural material. In all studied high entropy alloys, one alloy system named refractory high entropy alloys, which are exclusively based on the refractory metals of W, Ta, Nb, Mo, Hf, Zr, Ti, V, exhibits excellent elevated temperature properties [10][11][12][13][14]. For example, NbMoTaW and VNbMoTaW alloys have high compressive yield strength of 405 MPa and 477 MPa at 1600 o C [15]. HfMoTaTiZr and HfMoNbTaTiZr alloys have the compressive yield strength of 404 MPa and 556 MPa at 1200 o C [16]. Most reported refractory high entropy alloys are composed of a single disordered body-centered cubic (BCC) solid solution phase or the BCC phase is the dominant phase [17][18][19][20][21].

However, these refractory high entropy alloys have a high density. In the past few decades, the refractory intermetallic compounds and their composites have been extensively studied as candidate materials for elevated temperature applications [22,23]. For example, Nb-Si based ultrahigh temperature alloys have shown to possess great potential such as the higher melting points (above 1750 o C) and lower density (6.6-7.2 g/cm 3 ) for as alternative materials compared with Ni-based superalloys [24].

The equiatomic MoNbHfZrTi alloy has been reported recently, which has a single BCC phase with high phase stability and has yield strength of 1719 MPa at room temperature [21]. In this paper, the concentration of Mo and Hf with the higher density and cost is reduced to prepare the Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTi refractory alloy as the base alloy which will be also reported in another paper. This alloy still remains the single BCC phase and has a comprehensive strength and plasticity. Si is selected for incorporation into the Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTi alloy to generate the alloys with lower density and cost, and higher strength with adequate ductility. The phase constitutes, microstructure evolution and mechanical properties of Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTiSi x (x value in molar ratio, x=0, 0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7, 0.9) were investigated and discussed. The two main aims are 1) to prepare the M-Si based (M is Mo, Nb, Hf, Zr and Ti) composites that contains a ductile BCC
div.formula: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 3
div.p: phase and a intermetallic silicide phase with high strength and lower density, and 2) to optimize the Si content with better microstructure and properties and provide a reference for further tuning the compositions.

div.head: Experimental procedures
div.p: Alloy ingots of the Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTiSi x (x=0, 0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7, 0.9 denoted as alloy Si 0.1 , Si 0.3 , Si 0.5 , Si 0.7 , Si 0.9, respectively) were prepared by arc melting pure elements with purity higher than 99.6 wt.% under high-purity argon atmosphere inside a water-cooled copper hearth. All specimens were re-melted five times to improve the chemical homogeneity. The cooling rate has an important effect on the microstructure especially the grain size. During the process of preparing specimens, there are some factors influencing the cooling rate such as the melting electric current, melting time, the size of the specimen. Every specimen has the same weight of 60g. Each smelting of every specimen was melted for two minutes after completely melting with the same electric current of 450A. The lowermost part of the specimen that is directly contact with the water-cooled crucible has the highest cooling rate, so the microstructure is usually fine equiaxed grains. The uppermost part solidifies lastly in which there may be some solidification defects such as shrinkages. The cooling rate for the middle part is same and the microstructure is uniform. Thus all samples tested and analyzed are cut from the middle part of the specimen. The crystal structure was characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) with the 2 theta scan ranging from 20 o to 100 o at a speed of 5 o /min and the typical radiation condition was 45 KV and 40 mA with a copper target. The microstructure was investigated by the scanning electron microscope (SEM) and transmission electron microscope (TEM). The chemical compositions were analyzed by SEM with energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS). Vickers hardness, HV, was measured on polished cross-section surfaces under a 1 Kg load applied for 20 s. The hardness values were averaged by nine measurements at least for each specimen. The room temperature compressive properties were evaluated using an Instron 5569 testing machine. The test specimens are in the shape of a cylinder (φ4 mm × 6 mm). The strain rate is 1×10 -3 s -1 . Each alloy was tested for four times under the same testing conditions.

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D
div.p: ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 4

div.head: XRD analysis
div.p: The XRD patterns of the as-cast Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTiSi x alloy are shown in Fig. 1. The base alloy Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTi is composed of a single BCC phase. With the addition of Si, some other peaks appeared. According to the JCPDS cards, the multiple peaks match well with the Zr 5 Si 3 phase (65-3603) when Si≤0.3, and the peaks match well with the Zr 3 Ti 2 Si 3 phase (47-1339) when Si≥0.5.

The Zr 5 Si 3 phase and Zr 3 Ti 2 Si 3 phase belong to the same space group of P63/mcm (193). They have the same crystal structure of hexagonal close-packed (HCP) crystal structure. According to the following chemical compositions, this phase contains all five metal elements of Mo, Nb, Hf, Zr and Ti. Thus, this phase can be called as M 5 Si 3 phase in the alloys containing Si element. The intensity of these peaks corresponding to the M 5 Si 3 phase increases as the Si content increases, which indicates the content of the M 5 Si 3 phase increases with the addition of Si. When the molar ratio of Si reaches to 0.9, the intensity of the peaks corresponding to the M 5 Si 3 phase is stronger than that of the BCC phase, which indicates the M 5 Si 3 phase becomes the dominant phase. And all peaks of the BCC phase are shifted to the right which demonstrates the lattice parameter of the BCC phase is reduced with the increase of Si. <Fig. 1>

div.head: Microstructure evolution
div.p: Fig. 2 shows the backscattered electron (BSE) images of the as-cast Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTiSi x alloys. The chemical compositions of different regions labelled using the blue, red and yellow frames in Fig. 2 are listed in Table 1. The chemical compositions of the base alloy Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTi or Si 0 are very close to the nominal compositions as shown in Table 1 and its microstructure exhibits no obvious feature, in which all elements are distributed homogenously.

After adding Si into the base alloy, Si 0.1 alloy exhibits obvious dendritic and interdendritic structure. The interdendrites are composed of interlamellar two phases. The chemical compositions analysis shows that there is no any Si element detected in the dendrites and Si element is only detected in the interdendrites. The exact chemical compositions of the two lamellar structure are not be detected because of their small dimension. According to the XRD results, there are only two phases of BCC phase and M 5 Si 3 phase in this alloy. Thus one phase in the interdendrites is the same as that in the dendrites. It is well known that the lighter elements are darker in the BSE images. It can be inferred that the dark lamellar phase is M 5 Si 3 phase. It Si 0.3 alloy also exhibits the dendritic structure and the interdendrites are the lamellar structure while the volume of the interdendrites increases compared with Si 0.1 alloy. With the further increase of Si content, some large dark phase forms. In Si 0.5 alloy, some irregularly shaped dark phase forms in the dendrites or at the edge of the interdendrites. When the content of Si is 0.7, the dark phases exhibit lath like structure. The volume fraction of the lath like structure increases when the content of Si reaches to 0.9. According to the results of XRD and chemical compositions, it can be fairly asserted that these dark phases labelled using the yellow frames are also M 5 Si 3 phase. The chemical compositions analysis shows that the BCC phase is enriched with Mo, Nb and Ti while the M 5 Si 3 phase is enriched with Zr. The Hf element is distributed in all studied alloys. It can be concluded that the microstructure is proeutectic phase of BCC solid solution phase and eutectic structure of BCC phase and M 5 Si 3 phase in Si 0.1 and Si 0.3 alloys, the microstructure tends to exhibit the proeutectic phase of M 5 Si 3 phase and eutectic structure of BCC phase and M 5 Si 3 phase in Si 0.5 , Si 0.7 and Si 0.9 alloys. Thus, it can be inferred that the microstructure may exhibit the evolution from hypoeutectic structure to eutectic structure and then to hypereutectic structure with the increase of Si concentration in Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTiSi x alloys.

div.head: <Fig. 2> <Table 1>
div.p: To further investigate the effect of Si on the microstructure, the Si 0 and Si 0.1 alloys were etched using the hydrofluoric acid, nitric acid and distilled water (HF:HNO3:H2O=1:1:8) as shown in Fig. 3. The base Si 0 alloy without Si element exhibits the dendritic and interdendritic structure and the obvious primary dendrite and the secondary dendrites can be observed as labelled using the blue lines in Fig. 3 (a). And the Si 0.1 alloy tends to exhibit the cellular dendritic structure. The average gain size in Si 0.1 alloy is smaller than that of the base Si 0 alloy.

div.head: <Fig. 3>
div.p: Fine details of the microstructure of Si 0.1 and Si 0.5 alloys were studied using TEM and the crystal structure of phases are determined from the analysis of selected area electron diffraction patterns. All results are shown in Fig. 4 There are two regions of B and C near the block M 5 Si 3 phase. Region B contains some narrow black fringes which are too fine to detect. While the selected area electron diffraction pattern shows that the region B has the same BCC crystal structure with the very similar lattice parameter. The EDS chemical compositions analysis shows that both regions are enriched with Ti and depleted with Zr. The difference is that region C has a high content of Mo while region B has few Mo. This phenomenon has also observed in the base Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTi alloy which is reported in other paper. <Fig. 4> <Fig. 5>

div.head: Mechanical properties
div.p: Mechanical properties of the as-cast Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTiSi x alloy were studied using compressive testing and Hardness. The stress-strain curves are shown in Fig. 6. With a small amount addition of Si, both the yield strength and plasticity of Si 0.1 alloy are improved compared with that of the base alloy. When the content of Si is higher than 0.1, the yield strength increases while the plasticity decreases as shown in Fig. 7.
Microhardness values of the as-cast Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTiSi x alloys are listed in Fig. 7.

Evidentially, Si content has a very pronounced effect on the hardness of the alloys. The hardness increases with the increase of Si content. Without the addition of Si, the hardness is 398 HV while the hardness reaches to 638 HV when the content of Si is 0.9. <Fig. 6> <Fig. 7>

div.head: Phase prediction
div.p: From the alloy design point of view, phase selection is an important topic for developing novel alloys with required properties. The high mixing entropy is a dominant factor for facilitating the formation of simple phases for high entropy alloys. Thus, the Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTiSi x alloys are
div.formula: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 7
div.p: only composed of two phases that are much lower than the phase numbers predicted using the phase rule. The simple phases are basic and key aspect for alloy development and application. So far, several criteria have been proposed for predicting phase formation such as mixing enthalpy, mixing entropy, atomic size difference, and valence electron concentration [26][27][28][29]. However, these parameters are usually used to be criteria of the formation of simple solid solutions or intermetallic for high entropy alloys. If there is formation of intermetallic in high entropy alloy, which intermetallic will form is not predicted. For example, many kinds of intermetallic silicides may form such as Mo 5 Si 3 , Mo 3 Si, Nb 5 Si 3 , Nb 3 Si, Hf 3 Si 2 , Hf 5 Si 4 , Zr 5 Si 4 , Zr 3 Si 2 , Zr 2 Si, Ti 5 Si 3 , Ti 5 Si 4 , TiSi 2 for the studied alloys in this paper based on the binary alloy phase diagrams of Mo, Nb, Hf, Zr, Ti with Si, while only one disordered BCC solid solution and one silicide phase of M 5 Si 3 phase form in this Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTiSi x alloys even though when the content of Si reaches to 0.9. According to the results of the XRD and chemical composition analysis, the intermetallic M 5 Si 3 phase contains five kinds of metal atoms, in which the fraction of Zr atoms are the highest that may be attributed to the strongest binding strength between Zr atoms and Si atoms. The values of the mixing enthalpy calculated by Miedema's model for Mo, Nb, Hf, Zr, and Ti with Si are -35, -56, -77, -88 and -66 KJ/mol [25]. Zr atoms with Si have the most negative enthalpy which indicates Zr atoms have the strongest binding strength with Si atoms. The mutual interaction between constituent elements is also a key issue for the prediction of phase formation. However, the above factors do not explain why only one M 5 Si 3 intermetallic phase forms in the studied alloys. It can be found that all metal elements except Hf can form M 5 Si 3 -typed intermetallic phase and these M 5 Si 3 -typed intermetallic phase form at higher temperature compared with other intermetallic silicides form the binary alloy phase diagrams of Mo, Nb, Hf, Zr, Ti with Si. Thus the M 5 Si 3 -typed intermetallic phase will preferentially form during the solidification process. The high temperature M 5 Si 3 -typed intermetallic phase can keep retaining to the room temperature in the following solidification due to the significant effect of the sluggish diffusion in the high entropy alloys. The stability of the M 5 Si 3 -typed intermetallic phase will be further investigated in the next work.

div.head: Effect of Si addition on mechanical properties
div.p: The results of this work demonstrate that the addition of Si to Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTi alloy have very beneficial effects. The hardness and yield strength increase with the addition of Si. The

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D
div.p: ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 8 increase of the yield strength is mainly attributed to the formation of M 5 Si 3 phase. The main strengthening mechanism of the Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTi alloy with a single solid solution phase is solution strengthening. With the formation and increase of M 5 Si 3 phase in the alloy with Si, the second phase strengthening becomes more and more prominent. The eutectic structure reduced by the addition of Si has more interfaces to inhibit dislocation movement, which may cause the further increase of yield strength.

Both the strength and the plasticity are improved for Si 0.1 alloy, which may be attributed to the following reasons. The one main reason is the grain refinement as above mentioned. The addition of Si changes the microstructure from the coarse dendritic and interdendritic structure with obvious primary dendrite and secondary dendrites to the relatively fine cellular dendritic structure. The other possible reason is that Si atoms despoil some metal atoms especially Zr atoms to form M 5 Si 3 phase. The configurational randomness or the entropy value of the BCC phase for Si 0.1 alloy is reduced compared with the base alloy Si 0 . Thus, the solution strengthening for the BCC phase decreases and the BCC phase is the dominant phase so the plasticity of Si 0.1 alloy is improved. This can be verified from the XRD result that the diffraction peaks of the BCC phase shift to the right which indicates that the lattice parameter of the BCC phase decreases with the addition of Si element. The second phase strengthening induced from the intermetallic M 5 Si 3 phase increases the strength and the M 5 Si 3 phase is very fine. The lamellar spacing of eutectic structure composed of M 5 Si 3 phase and BCC phase is only about 100 nm. In addition to the above factors, the BCC phase with improved plasticity is the dominant phase and the amount of M 5 Si 3 phase has relatively small volume. Thus the small amount addition of Si not only increases the strength but also brings the plasticity improved. With the increase of Si, the size and volume of M 5 Si 3 phase increase, leading to the increase of strength and hardness and the decrease of plasticity.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: In this study, Si is added into Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTi alloy to produce the BCC/M 5 Si 3 in-situ compounds. The microstructure and mechanical properties were characterized and discussed.
Based on obtained results and analysis, the conclusions can be drawn as follows.

(1) The Si-containing alloys are composed of BCC phase and intermetallic M 5 Si 3 phase, the (2) When Si content is lower than x=0.5, the microstructure exhibits the hypoeutectic structure, the microstructure is very closed to the eutectic structure and the microstructure is the hypereutectic structure. Table 1 The chemical compositions of the as-cast Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTiSi x alloy: A, B and C refer to the regions labelled using the blue, red and yellow frames. 1. In-situ (Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTi) BCC /M 5 Si 3 compounds were prepared successfully.
2. Mo 0.5 NbHf 0.5 ZrTiSi x alloy has a BCC phase and M 5 Si 3 phase.
3. Microstructure evolves from hypoeutectic to hypereutectic with increasing Si.
4. The addition of Si increases the hardness and strength.
5. The yield strength and plasticity are improved for Si 0.1 alloy.

figure.figDesc: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 5 can be concluded that Si 0.1 alloy is composed of the primary dendritic BCC phase and the interdendentic eutectic structure of BCC phase and M 5 Si 3 phase observed from the Fig. 2 (b).

and Fig. 5. Fig. 4 (a) shows the morphology of the interdendritic structure in Si 0.1 alloy, which is lamellar structure and the lamellar spacing of the M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 6 eutectic structure is about 100 nm. Fig. 4 (b) is the selected area electron diffraction of dendrite which is BCC phase. Region A has the same crystal with the dendrites and region B has a HCP crystal structure as shown in Fig. 4. These results are consistent with the XRD result. In Si 0.5 alloy, some block M 5 Si 3 phase appears with the HCP crystal structure as shown in Fig. 5 (b).
